page.title: 07Ecology,Geology,Wildlife
page.content: The Twyi and its tributary, the Gwenlais, flow through an area were the base rocks are mainly sedimentary, shales and Dolomitic limestones. There is evidence of glaciation in the outwash gravels and boulder clay in te valley and peneplained uplands. Rainfall exceeds 50" Temperatures are relatively mild, with unimpeded maritime influences from the south west. The problem of acid rain in the Tywi Valley is being studied by the Welsh Water Authority The Gwenlais, with neutral pH, is one of the best nursery streams in Wales for salmon and sewin. It supports kingfishers, herons and dippers, birds which are evidence of healthy waters.. The endangered red kite, peregrine falcons, polecats, bats, otters and red squirrels are also to be seen. Thre is little evidence of farm
